body: @JoshMcCullough please ask usage questions in discussions or on the user mailing list.  NetBeans 16 is no longer support - try NetBeans 21 (or imminent 22).  The option is in `Tools / Options / Java / Gradle`.

@EtienneDelepine 
Could you write your exact steps?
I can't reproduce it.
1. Create a new file
2. Type `for` & CC
3. Select `for` template
```php
<?php

for // CC & select for template here
```

Did you check formatting options?

![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/738383/207580e2-e524-466f-878c-ae9891f3e73c)
Please also write your formatting option.
lets use a more reasonable issue title

> The problem only happens in the DEB package

how do you know that? Does this mean you tried the zip and it worked or does this mean that it worked for you on windows but not on debian?

> The border options had blank fields in its dropdown..

this makes me think that this is no packaging issue, but rather a graphical issue related to context menus. Can you post a screenshot?
closing, feel free to reopen if there is a reproducer
duplicate of https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/3962

the stack trace looks like it is walking a cyclic java module tree or something similar. Difficult to say without seeing the project - it might be a invalid `module-info.java` cycle or something like that.

it had some ant project stack frames in it, would be worth a try and check if it works with maven like @johntor suggested.
looks like the compiler is inlining the String as constant
is this still a problem or did this only happen once?

It's strange because it is not happening in all files.
I tested in a project I'm working on. In a new PHP file it works, as well as some PHP class methods. But in others, it happens.
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/50837574/2161c28a-1210-40c8-8911-c4be2b30378e
The only point I found is in a PHP class of more than 5000 lines, it starts failing when the number of line increases. 
It is not only related to the number of lines because change the content of a line can allow it to function or not (without error on the page), even the change of a IF test. This not occured if the file contains less than 5000 lines.

I don't really see the benefit to deduplicate results of "find usages". A usage is a usage, no matter how the code is formatted - if a method is called 3 times I would expect 3 results in that list. Selecting individual results will jump the cursor to the right place, deduplication would remove information and complicate things.

The result will also depend on what you had selected, this is for the `JFrame` _class_:
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/3d132b5c-9bea-49f4-88f2-022e261eb286)

this would be for the `JFrame()` _constructor_ which shows only one hit:
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/fe411060-a8d7-4cb0-bf8b-6f9729b33673)

edit: find usage for the `frame` _instance_ would of course also give different results etc

> Now, how shall we proceed? Shall I try to replicate the issue with simple projects only, such that I can post them here? Or is there a similar issue ticket already?

@herkrath I took a look and I don't think there is a similar ticket involving stack overflow. If you can create a small reproducer - I am sure it would help, however it likely won't be easy to come up with one.
can confirm that bumping the source level above 11 will break the method profiler

@mbien check out #2949 One possibility might be to look at consuming the VisualVM code as a library?  It's published to Maven - https://central.sonatype.com/artifact/org.graalvm.visualvm.modules/org-graalvm-visualvm-lib-profiler

@neilcsmith-net well, tbh I don't use the NB profiler at all personally - https://github.com/async-profiler/async-profiler took over all my profiling needs, it truly is an awesome tool and completely IDE independent.

Thats why I didn't plan to put time into this, I would have quickly checked if it is fixable thats all ;)

@mbien me neither most of the time.  Having the profiler slowly decaying and no-one working on it is not a solution - either we need someone to work on it, we integrate with a third-party library, or we drop it and look at third-party tool integration instead?
It would be nice if you could find and provide an example to reproduce it.

Hi,

I am baffled at how this Windows issue remains opened yet without a path to
resolution. If the options fix continued to work it would be fine. It no
longer does. While it may duplicate a problem first discovered, in NB 13,
that the fix/hack no longer works makes this a new problem. I will have to
abandon NetBeans as most of what I do is preparing presentations or write
about programming.

I would be happy to look into this matter. I just need to know where in the
Editor's code Select/Copy/Paste/Cut is handled. Or, is the default
behaviour of Java exclusively responsible for these operations and
therefore there is no dedicated code? Has an update defeated or disabled
the fix/hack? There must be an event where this disconnects from Windows
and subsequently only works within the editor that could be identified.

Now a short story. A few years ago I had some issues with Arquillian when
teaching server side programming. I knew the developers at RedHat and they
made numerous suggestions. Eventually I resolved the issue. In a casual
discussion with these developers they revealed that they did not have a
single Windows machine in their office. They had never observed Arquillian
running on Windows. So, may I ask, is anyone who is a committer to NetBeans
working on Windows rather than Linux or MacOS?

I will now crawl back under my rock,

Ken Fogel



On Thu, May 23, 2024, 2:20 AM Michael Bien ***@***.***> wrote:

> Closed #7396 <https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/7396> as not
> planned.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/7396#event-12904027002>, or
> unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AA7AMUKC5URVLSU5SV2Z7JDZDWDC5AVCNFSM6AAAAABIEQUAKGVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV45UABCJFZXG5LFIV3GK3TUJZXXI2LGNFRWC5DJN5XDWMJSHEYDIMBSG4YDAMQ>
> .
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

You've been pointed to the equivalent issue for IntelliJ IDEA in the past. Are you baffled there, too? Or do you think it's something that the tools can't solve since it's more likely a JDK-level thing, given that the issue is present in two Java Swing based IDEs?

Also, of the committers who do use or have access to Windows (which includes me) no-one can reproduce it!  It affects _some_ Windows users, but what makes this a problem for some and not for others remains a mystery.

> So, may I ask, is anyone who is a committer to NetBeans working on Windows rather than Linux or MacOS?

speaking for myself: I do avoid windows whenever I can. It still is the worst platform for sw development, file path limitations, [process arg length limitations](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7237/commits/15cbc0a4c17fa3621597b53dba9b8c184df1edf3) slow file systems in general etc. Not to mention that I had to press 11 times "no you can't have my data" the last time I installed it in vbox (the recent news about ads in the start menu doesn't help either).

So I have no plans to investigate a race condition on windows in my free time which I can't reproduce (yes i tried on win 10 and 11) and which could be influenced by any combination of antivirus or other addware which ships with a typical windows box.

But anyone is welcome to contribute, the linked issue has 36 participants with a severe lack of PRs.

Incidentally, quick search at the latest on the IntelliJ comparable issue found this https://github.com/JetBrains/JetBrainsRuntime/commit/16257c3de7e858c8da3e453548f290e33718372d  Which does point to it being a JDK bug.  Unfortunately, we're not in a position to patch our own JDK!

@omniprof once that change hits a release, try running NetBeans on top of the JetBrains Runtime JDK.  If that also addresses the issue in NetBeans, maybe we have the start of trying to find a workaround or pushing for a fix upstream.  In fact, might already be in released versions judging from the bug report comments - patch might be reapplied hence commit showing more recent.

I have discovered that it is possible to make copy/paste on Windows work after it fails if you have a second tab open in the editor. I am working out a consistent procedure to get copy/paste to work after it fails without restarting NetBeans. It is interesting that copy/paste in NetBeans between tabs never fails, even if it failed when copied outside of NetBeans.

Ken

It's still a problem with NB21: I noticed it last week again, though I do not see the problem often.
Looking forward to [test-drive](https://github.com/sormuras/bach-demo-junit) this feature! 🤓

Thanks for considering my suggestion and posting a nice example screenshot.  To me, it still looks odd to see line 16 twice in your first screenshot.  I do see your point that every usage is important, but I was imagining that you could still highlight (bold) each occurrence on a deduplicated line, and even advance the cursor to each instance when using the "Next Occurrence" toolbar button. So the only real change would be fewer lines in the results. Anyway, no biggie... The idea was just an optimization, certainly not a bug, and probably of very low importance compared to others.  Thanks for keeping Netbeans going!

Sorry for the long wait. Been a while since I tried Swing. Looks like I can't reproduce the issue anymore. I'll be closing for now. Maybe someone someday can find out what the bug was about. (I tried both latest and previous versions)
thanks, in case you are able to come up with a small reproducer, please post it. (but I fear this might be an index issue or something like that)

Hello, is NetBeans still planned to get published on OpenVSX? 
The only Java extension on the store is Redhat's and having another option would be great, more in cases when it breaks, so it doesn't require switching IDEs/code editors. 
Thank you for the hard work!
we can probably merge this now since devs are now able to switch to the NB22 release while working on netbeans

If this is a JDK bug, so why is only Netbeans Platform affected and no other Java program on my machine. And yes: all using the same Java installation (JDK 17 Temurin). 
Other programs with reliable Copy Paste:
* DBeaver
* JEdit
* some Java Swing Software of my own
* ... 

I did not try IntelliJ or Eclipse. 

However, all my Netbeans platform applications have the same problem.
possibly for the same reason why I can't reproduce it at all
@mbien Possible. Maybe it's time to start writing this thing from scratch instead of poking into the existing implementation.

@matthiasblaesing Hi, I was unable to isolate the problem :-(. I tried to play with that however our Java web project is quite big. Could it be possible to add some logging in case of an exception e.g. into method `org.netbeans.modules.maven.j2ee.MavenJsfReferenceImplementationProvider.artifactPathFor` or into `org.apache.maven.artifact.resolver.DefaultArtifactResolver.resolve`? This might help to see what exactly resulted in that exception.
Thanks for your help! Vít

@wumpz sure, feel free to work on it! No-one currently contributing to this project can reproduce, so none of them is likely to _volunteer_ their time to chasing shadows.

Or you could try running with JBR as mentioned above and see if the issue is still reproducible or not. That JetBrains felt that they had to patch their JDK to fix a similar issue means that should at least be considered here.

```
INFO [org.netbeans.Stamps]: cannot rename (#0): C:\Users\spamm\AppData\Local\NetBeans\Cache\21\all-layers.dat
...
WARNING [org.netbeans.Stamps]: Error saving cache C:\Users\spamm\AppData\Local\NetBeans\Cache\21\all-layers.dat
INFO [org.netbeans.Stamps]: Could not delete: C:\Users\spamm\AppData\Local\NetBeans\Cache\21\all-layers.dat
java.io.IOException: Could not delete: C:\Users\spamm\AppData\Local\NetBeans\Cache\21\all-layers.dat
	at org.netbeans.Stamps.deleteCache(Stamps.java:515)
	at org.netbeans.Stamps.access$200(Stamps.java:69)
[catch] at org.netbeans.Stamps$Store.store(Stamps.java:709)
	at org.netbeans.Stamps$Worker.run(Stamps.java:887)
```

NetBeans can't delete that file for some reason. You could try to restart your system to make sure all file locks are released, then remove this folder: `C:\Users\spamm\AppData\Local\NetBeans\Cache\21`.

Once done NB should hopefully work again.
@mbien stamp file aspect is odd, but this looks more like the issue fixed in #7334

@neilcsmith-net you are right. It was my first thought too but I got distracted by the exception in the log. `nbjavacapi` module isn't loaded so its the same symptom.

@cho-mik this issue is fixed in NB 22 which should be available next week. If you want to use NB 21 till then, try resetting your config in `C:\Users\spamm\AppData\Roaming\NetBeans\21`. Once you start NetBeans again, create a new maven project right away without opening the plugin manager or the options and all modules should initialize properly.

I just stumbled upon this bug today with the same conditions: NB21, JDK21, sourcelevel21, Focused(instrumented) profiling. I use netbeans and all the build-in-tools like the profiler, git-support, maven ...  a LOT the last 15 years in a offline environment without access to the internet, so i was very happy that netbeans comes "with batteries includes": Download, unzip and ready to rumble.
It would be a shame for such a beautiful, solid IDE to starve slowly.
So: please, please, fix this if you can :-)
Thank you

lets say you have `project_a` which uses `project_b` as regular maven dependency.

If you open both projects in NB, you should be able to navigate directly between them. NB will automatically jump to the sources instead of opening the jar.

If `project_b` is a dependency from maven central for example, you can download the source via right click (or you jump into the jar and pres the download button from there).

no need to attach sources or anything like that.
@fsilkswan have a nice holiday! Great place.

ok, thank you!

I have another change to offer. We could now remove the JDK manifest entries entirely, since the build adds them by looking at the `javac.release` property if they aren't there yet.
 - https://github.com/mbien/netbeans/commit/8db6aabca483f87ccafa1782bbe91a4d3c7671d2

This would simplify the module configuration to a single value in `project.properties`.

to validate this I diffed the manifest dump of all jars before/after a rebuild using this script:
```bash
find nbbuild/netbeans/ -type f -iname '*.jar' | sort | while read line || [[ -n $line ]];
do
    echo "$line/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF"
    unzip -p $line META-INF/MANIFEST.MF
done
```
checking all jars in `nbbuild/netbeans/` should be sufficient, right? @matthiasblaesing

i could squash this into my other commit

The archetypes are present and the result from the JavaEE 1.5 one looks sane to me. So I pushed a PR that readds them.

For the EOL part: I would say JavaEE as a whole is EOL. Oracle did a pretty good job at destroying it. Lets hope JakartaEE has a good future.
@mbien +1 to removing those that match. There can be times where they deliberately don't match and those should probably be reviewed separately.

> +1 to removing those that match. There can be times where they deliberately don't match and those should probably be reviewed separately.

well, as you can see in https://github.com/mbien/netbeans/commit/af7798df16a63f93e6a097e09c2c9dcce578523a and https://github.com/mbien/netbeans/commit/8db6aabca483f87ccafa1782bbe91a4d3c7671d2, I bumped `javac.release` to the value of `OpenIDE-Module-Java-Dependencies`. There was luckily no instance where lang level was `>` manifest attribute

the reason it wasn't synced in the first place was likely due to https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/6817 which this PR would fix.

J2EE 1.4 is 25 years old (1999?). Can anything still run this today? I am just a bit worried that this will spawn more bug reports for software nobody is supporting anymore. (and nobody should create new projects for outside of nostalgia reasons)

> J2EE 1.4 is 25 years old (1999?). Can anything still run this today? I am just a bit worried that this will spawn more bug reports for software nobody is supporting anymore.

Removing this is more work than restoring the archetype configuration.

> There was luckily no instance where lang level was `>` manifest attribute

That scenario would fail CI tests. I saw your release changes. But there are a few that specify a higher JDK requirement and use reflection to compile with a lower language level. eg. External processes jdk9 shouldn't just have this done, it should be rewritten to use the APIs directly, and folded back into the main module. That's why I asked if we could split out and review those few separately?

> ...That's why I asked if we could split out and review those few separately?

sure. I also just realized while jogging that I broke gradle again since i reverted my own revert (https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7367) with this by setting release to 17 in the first commit :facepalm:
 - https://github.com/mbien/netbeans/commit/b31e7763b86339c231acecf4188bc50cab4458d4 reverts
 - branch diff https://github.com/apache/netbeans/compare/master...mbien:netbeans:java-modules-using-jdk9-plus

i can do this next week. Lets remove everything below EE 8, I checked [wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakarta_EE) and J2EE was synced with the java release in early days, so J2EE 1.4 actually means Java SE 1.4.

Jakarta/Java EE 8 would be the lowest release NB realistically could still "support".

@mbien DON'T! From my POV going from "fix faulty PR when introducing support for JavaEE8" to rip out random parts of JavaEE support is an overreaction.

The baseline question is: What do you define as "JavaEE/J2SE support"? The ability to generate a maven project for it? The ability to generate an ant project for it. The ability to parse the deployment descriptors?

> From my POV going from "fix faulty PR when introducing support for JavaEE8" to rip out random parts of JavaEE support is an overreaction.

I would filter out versions below EE 8 from the new-project wizzard like indicated under the issue https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/3681#issuecomment-2131029377

> > From my POV going from "fix faulty PR when introducing support for JavaEE8" to rip out random parts of JavaEE support is an overreaction.
> 
> I would filter out versions below EE 8 from the new-project wizzard like indicated under the issue [#3681 (comment)](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/3681#issuecomment-2131029377)

Whatever. I can't stop you, but I think it is wrong to introduce more complexity instead of just fixing the typo.

I was getting ready to ask whether we can integrate this, so thanks for being quicker. I am +1 on integrating this, and +1 on removing obvious unnecessary manifest entries. Keeping those that are not obvious separate would surely be good.

Thanks for working on this!

awesome! Squashed and pushed. Your changes are the first commit (unmodified, just squashed), the javac.release/manifest updates are in the second commit.

Planning to merge today, if anyone still wants to look through it - there is still time to make changes.

@edrobal there are breaking changes in JDK22. For NB21 use JDK21. NB22 (currently being in release) will support running on JDK22+
looks like this opened another can of worms

looks like the language version bump is causing groovy tests to fail since they have to test on JDK 8 due to https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/4904

I am working on a fix. The recent changes in the build made it easier to bump groovy to more recent JDKs since most pass out of the box now.

@mbien Thanks -- wouldn't it be better if I downgrade for a while lsp.api back to 8 ? Since the language bump was just because of `CompletableFuture.failedFuture` which I can achieve in a different way.

@sdedic we have to bump the remaining few "stuck stuck with 8" tests anyway at some point. I am running them locally now and 98% pass, rest seem to be fixable by updating the golden files (some completion tests are JDK API sensitive for example).

Last time I tried this far more failed due to module system issues, but it seems it is resolved now and it looks much better.
this should fix it I think https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7415

groovy/groovy.editor

Thanks, the dev build improves the situation but it is still incomplete as it makes the validity of the `await` statement dependent on there also being an `export` statement in the file, which while recommended practice, is not a language requirement.
where do you see 3 state check boxes in NB? The only place I remember would be some trees, where the third state indicates that some but not all of the child nodes are checked (e.g hints settings).

My example screenshots are from the Properties window, indicating the properties of the selection in the Projects window. As you say, the third state indicates a boolean property that is not the same for all selected nodes. In my case I'm working with a gradle project, and the selected files are gradle.properties files.

Adding the additional library to facilitate this isn't feasible.  That module shouldn't depend on FlatLaf.

However, it looks like we could try `putClientProperty("JButton.selectedState", "indeterminate");` in the `Boolean3WayEditor`? See https://github.com/JFormDesigner/FlatLaf/blob/main/flatlaf-core/src/main/java/com/formdev/flatlaf/FlatClientProperties.java#L123
